page-wallets-hero-heading: Wallets are the gateway to using Ethereum.
page-wallets-hero-subtitle: Wallets let you interact with Ethereum, just like web browsers let you use the internet.
page-wallets-hero-alt: Illustration of a robot with a vault for a body, representing an Ethereum wallet
page-wallets-quick-links-learn-item-3: How to keep your wallet safe
page-wallets-quick-links-setup-heading: How to set up an Ethereum wallet
page-wallets-what-is-description-1: An Ethereum wallet is an application you use to access and control your Ethereum account.
page-wallets-what-is-description-2: With a wallet, you can send and receive payments, sign into apps, play games, verify your identity, trade, and collect digital items.
page-wallets-what-is-highlight-title: Your Ethereum wallet is the app that creates your Ethereum account
page-wallets-what-is-highlight-item-1: Send, receive, and manage money or digital items
page-wallets-what-is-highlight-item-2: Use decentralized applications built on Ethereum
page-wallets-wallet-does-heading: What does an Ethereum wallet actually do?
page-wallets-wallet-does-item-1-desc: Keep your ether (ETH) and NFTs safe and accessible.
page-wallets-wallet-does-item-2-desc: Transfer crypto to anyone, anytime—no bank required.
page-wallets-wallet-does-item-3-desc: Use Ethereum apps by connecting your wallet—one account, endless apps.
page-wallets-wallet-does-item-4-desc: Buy, sell, and showcase digital items directly from your wallet.
page-wallets-wallet-does-item-5-desc: Approve actions like trades or votes securely with your wallet.
page-wallets-wallet-does-item-6-desc: Only you can access your wallet—no bans, no blocks.
page-wallets-wallet-vs-account-body-1: Your Ethereum wallet is the app you use to manage your Ethereum account.
page-wallets-wallet-vs-account-bullet-1: Your Ethereum account lives on the Ethereum blockchain.
page-wallets-wallet-vs-account-bullet-2: Your wallet holds the keys that give you access to your account.
page-wallets-wallet-vs-account-body-2: Think of your wallet like a personal portal for creating, accessing, and using your Ethereum account.
page-wallets-comparison-title: Wallets, accounts, keys, and addresses - explained
page-wallets-comparison-intro: Ethereum wallets involve accounts, keys, and addresses. An easy way to think about it is like email.
page-wallets-comparison-wallet-app-desc: The app you use to access your Ethereum account
page-wallets-comparison-email-app-desc: The app you use to access your email account
page-wallets-comparison-wallet-account-d: Stores your Ethereum addresses and the digital assets they hold
page-wallets-comparison-email-account-de: Stores your email addresses and the messages they hold
page-wallets-comparison-wallet-address-d: A unique string where people can send you funds
page-wallets-comparison-email-address-de: A unique string where people can send you messages
page-wallets-comparison-wallet-private-d: Used to log into your account and prove ownership
page-wallets-comparison-email-password-d: Used to log into your account and prove ownership
page-wallets-comparison-wallet-recovery-: A unique list of words you can use to restore access to your Ethereum account
page-wallets-comparison-email-reset-desc: A service that can help you restore access to your email account
page-wallets-comparison-outro: Just like email, you can have many Ethereum accounts in the same wallet app—and you can move your Ethereum account and balance to a different wallet app at any time.
page-wallets-key-concept-title: Key concept: How Ethereum wallets work
page-wallets-key-concept-desc: Every Ethereum account is secured by a pair of keys: a public key and a private key.
page-wallets-key-concept-public-line-1: Your public key is like your bank account number or email address.
page-wallets-key-concept-public-line-2: You can share it with others to identify your account and receive funds.
page-wallets-key-concept-public-line-3: Your public key is used to generate your public Ethereum address—a user-friendly version of the public key.
page-wallets-key-concept-private-line-1: Your private key is like your bank PIN or email password. Keep it secret at all times.
page-wallets-key-concept-private-line-2: Your private key gives you control over your account and lets you authorize transactions.
page-wallets-key-concept-private-line-3: Anyone with access to your private key can access your Ethereum account and funds.
page-wallets-key-concept-wallet-responsi: Your Ethereum wallet is responsible for:
Generating your Ethereum account and its unique public/private key pair
Allowing you to use your private key to interact with the Ethereum network
page-wallets-key-concept-how-it-works: How it works: When you want to send crypto or interact with a decentralized application, your wallet signs the transaction with your private key. This signature proves you are the legitimate owner of your account.
page-wallets-wallet-types-intro: Choose the style of wallet that fits how you like to use Ethereum.
page-wallets-wallet-types-row-1-desc: Use an app on your phone to send, receive, and log into apps. e.g. Rainbow, MetaMask Mobile
page-wallets-wallet-types-row-2-desc: Open your wallet in a web browser—no install needed. e.g. Coinbase Wallet (web), Frame
page-wallets-wallet-types-row-3-desc: Add a wallet to Chrome or Firefox to sign things as you go. e.g. MetaMask, Rabby
page-wallets-wallet-types-row-4-desc: Download software to manage everything locally. e.g. Exodus, Atomic Wallet
page-wallets-wallet-types-row-5-desc: Keep your keys offline with a physical device. e.g. Ledger, Trezor
page-wallets-wallet-types-row-6-desc: Requires more than one person to approve a payment or action. e.g. Safe, Tally
page-wallets-custodial-section-title: What do custodial and non-custodial mean?
page-wallets-custodial-non-title: Non-custodial wallets give you full control.
page-wallets-custodial-non-bullet-1: You have sole control over your account’s private key.
page-wallets-custodial-non-bullet-2: Only you can access your account and funds.
page-wallets-custodial-non-bullet-3: It is your responsibility to keep your private key safe.
page-wallets-custodial-cust-title: Custodial wallets are managed for you.
page-wallets-custodial-cust-bullet-1: The platform manages your account’s private key for you.
page-wallets-custodial-cust-bullet-2: The platform can freeze or restrict your account and funds.
page-wallets-custodial-cust-bullet-3: It is the platform’s responsibility to keep your private key safe.
page-wallets-custodial-tip: Tip: If it feels like you are logging into a bank or exchange, the wallet is probably custodial.
page-wallets-demo-description: See what it is like to set up and use an Ethereum wallet—no real money, no pressure.
page-wallets-safety-title: How to keep your Ethereum wallet safe
page-wallets-safety-intro: With a non-custodial wallet, you are in full control—and fully responsible for security. Follow these best practices and never share your private key or recovery phrase.
page-wallets-safety-tip-1-desc: Use strong passwords, keep software updated, and avoid downloading anything suspicious.
page-wallets-safety-tip-1-point-1: Your private key is the only way to approve transactions and prove ownership on Ethereum.
page-wallets-safety-tip-1-point-2: Your private key is stored wherever your wallet lives—phone, computer, browser, or hardware device.
page-wallets-safety-tip-1-point-3: If a hacker gets access to your device and compromises your private key, they can drain your wallet.
page-wallets-safety-tip-2-title: Back up your recovery phrase offline
page-wallets-safety-tip-2-desc: Write it down and keep it safe. Do not store it digitally.
page-wallets-safety-tip-2-point-1: Your wallet gives you a 12- or 24-word recovery phrase during setup.
page-wallets-safety-tip-2-point-2: It is the only backup for your account keys and funds if you lose access to your wallet app.
page-wallets-safety-tip-2-point-3: Anyone with this phrase can take all of your funds.
page-wallets-safety-tip-3-title: Bookmark your wallet and avoid fakes
page-wallets-safety-tip-3-desc: If you use a web wallet, bookmark it and double-check the URL before connecting.
page-wallets-safety-tip-3-point-1: Fake lookalike sites are a common scam.
page-wallets-safety-tip-3-point-2: Attackers impersonate legitimate wallets to steal recovery phrases, private keys, or signatures.
page-wallets-safety-tip-3-point-3: Be skeptical of ads, social posts, and unsolicited messages before you click.
page-wallets-safety-tip-4-desc: Verify the recipient, amount, token, and network before you hit "Confirm."
page-wallets-safety-tip-4-point-1: All transactions on Ethereum are final and irreversible.
page-wallets-safety-tip-4-point-2: Always pause and verify before signing.
page-wallets-safety-tip-4-point-3: On compromised devices or fake sites, malicious transactions can steal your funds or credentials.
page-wallets-custodial-aside-title: Not ready to manage your own wallet?
page-wallets-custodial-aside-body: Start with a custodial wallet from a trusted exchange, bank, or custodian. They will handle security for you, just like a traditional bank account. You can always switch to self-custody when you are ready.
page-wallets-features-description-1: Ethereum’s latest upgrades expanded what wallets can do.
page-wallets-features-description-2: The Pectra upgrade (May 2025) lets regular wallets enable programmable safety features and smoother app interactions.
page-wallets-features-row-1-before: Approve actions one at a time
page-wallets-features-row-1-after: Approve multiple actions in one go
page-wallets-features-row-2-before: Connect and reconnect your wallet to apps
page-wallets-features-row-2-after: Stay connected safely with session keys
page-wallets-features-row-3-after: Let apps act (with permission) while you are away
page-wallets-features-row-4-after: Recoverable smart wallets, custom spending limits, smarter approvals
page-wallets-features-row-5-before: Pay all gas fees in ETH
page-wallets-features-row-5-after: Pay gas fees with stablecoins like USDC or DAI
page-wallets-features-row-6-before: Give apps full access by default
page-wallets-features-row-6-after: Use granular access controls to limit risk
page-wallets-compare-title: Find the right wallet for you
page-wallets-compare-description: Compare features to pick the best wallet for your phone, desktop, hardware device, or browser.
page-wallets-faq-1-question: What is an Ethereum wallet and how does it work?
page-wallets-faq-1-answer:
An Ethereum wallet is an application you use to access and control your Ethereum account. It is how you send and receive crypto, log into apps, and prove ownership of your account—without needing an email or password.

Wallets manage your account’s two cryptographic keys: a public key for receiving assets and identifying your account, and a private key that acts like a password to approve transactions.
page-wallets-faq-2-question: Do I need a wallet to use Ethereum?
page-wallets-faq-2-answer:
Yes. A wallet is your gateway to Ethereum. Without one, you cannot hold ETH, use apps, send and receive assets, or manage digital items and NFTs.

Most Ethereum apps require you to connect a wallet—just like traditional apps need you to create an account before you can use them.
page-wallets-faq-3-question: What happens if I lose my wallet or recovery phrase?
page-wallets-faq-3-answer:
If you lose access to your wallet app (for example, if you lose your phone), you can restore your account and funds in a different wallet app using your backed-up recovery phrase.

If you lose your recovery phrase, there is no way to recover your account—your funds become permanently inaccessible. That is why backing it up securely is critical.

Ethereum’s Pectra upgrade (EIP-7702) introduced programmable wallet recovery so you can designate another wallet as a guardian. Many wallet apps are still rolling out these features—learn more about social recovery in Vitalik Buterin’s post.
page-wallets-faq-4-question: How do I keep my wallet safe?
page-wallets-faq-4-answer:
Write down your recovery phrase and store it somewhere private, safe, and offline—consider keeping two copies in different secure locations.

Never screenshot or share it. Avoid suspicious links and double-check every transaction before you sign.
page-wallets-faq-5-question: Can apps steal my crypto if I connect my wallet?
page-wallets-faq-5-answer:
No. Connecting your wallet does not give an app access to your funds—you still have to approve every transaction with your private key.

After you connect, only approve transactions you trust. Make sure you are on the legitimate app site, not a phishing clone, and verify all details before signing.
page-wallets-meta-title: Ethereum wallets: Buy, Store and Send crypto
page-wallets-meta-description: What you need to know to use Ethereum wallets.
page-wallets-get-some-alt: An illustration of a hand creating an ETH logo made of lego bricks
page-wallets-get-some-desc: ETH is the native crypto of Ethereum. You’ll need some ETH in your wallet to use Ethereum applications.
page-wallets-try-dapps-alt: An illustration of Ethereum community members working together
page-wallets-try-dapps-desc: Dapps are applications built on Ethereum. They are cheaper, fairer and kinder on your data than most traditional applications.
